context: In Methodism, Mary is honored as the Mother of God. Methodists do not have any additional teachings on the Virgin Mary except from what is mentioned in <a2_0>Scripture and the ecumenical Creeds<a2_0/>. As such, Methodists believe that Mary was conceived in her womb through the Holy Ghost and accept the doctrine of the Virgin Birth, although they, along with <b5_0>Orthodox Christians<b5_0/> and other Protestant Christians, reject the doctrine of <a0_0>the Immaculate Conception<a0_0/>. <a1_0><b7_0>John Wesley<b7_0/><a1_0/>, the principal founder of the Methodist movement within <a3_0><b8_0>the Church of <b6_0>England<b8_0/><b6_0/><a3_0/>, believed that Mary "continued a pure and unspotted virgin", thus upholding the doctrine of <a4_0>the perpetual virginity of Mary<a4_0/>. Contemporary Methodism does hold that Mary was a virgin before, during, and immediately after the birth of Christ. In addition, some Methodists also hold the doctrine of the Assumption of Mary as a pious opinion.
